title: If you couldn't get a novel traditionally published, would you self-publish it and move on to your next project, or would you keep re-drafting it in the hope that it might eventually get traditionally published? - Quora

response.answer_text: Question: If you couldn’t get a novel traditionally published, would you self-publish it and move on to your next project, or would you keep re-drafting it in the hope that it might eventually get traditionally published? Answer: Neither. That’s limited thinking deriving from a lack of imagination and research. That’s just the thinking of a bad author. First - let’s take a look at a couple of successful strategies that have been used. Lois McMaster Bujold wrote a great short science fiction novel. No one would publish it. She did NOT waste time fiddling with it. She wrote another novel. No one would publish it. She did not waste time fiddling with it. She wrote another novel in the same series. And again. The fourth one got an agent and publisher interested in publishing three of her novels. So - her first novel finally got published. And promptly won a Hugo. Not much point in polishing and fiddling with a novel that’s good enough to win a Hugo is there? Do NOT make the mistake of thinking that quality alone gets a book published or selling. Another example - another approach. Jim Butcher wrote several of his Science fantasy magical novels. Couldn’t get them published. So he spent his time attending Sci-fi conventions. Made some good contacts and got a publisher and … went on to become the best selling author we know today. So that’s two approaches the question doesn’t even consider. Why not? Probably because of a lack of imagination and research. How do I know about the above two stories? I did some research on this problem. So - what’s wrong with self-publishing? Nothing - provided you understand that it is the publisher who has to market the book. Example - The Alchemist was written by Paulo Coelho and published by a publisher with no marketing plan. Result - 2 sales in 2 years. No one can buy a book they’ve never heard of. He eventually regained the rights and got it published by a publisher who knew how to market it. Result - 60 million plus sales in 80 different languages. No point in polishing or fiddling with the book. And there is no point in self publishing unless you are prepared to create and implement the marketing plan. So - do you want to spend the next two years on marketing, or on writing another book? Conclusion. There is no point in fiddling and polishing a really good book that just needs an agent or publisher. There is no point in offering less than one’s best for publication anyway, but once one has done one’s best, don’t waste more time on it. When one has a publisher, spend time working with their demands. Otherwise progress in other ways. There is no point in self-publishing unless one is prepared to do the necessary marketing. Without that, one is just making it less likely that a traditional publisher will ever take it up. What one does need to do is some research into marketing and the problems of getting published, and then come up with a strategy to get yourself published. Jim Butcher came up with a good one. Sometimes it’s not what you write but who you know … Here’s a plot for your next story. No world building necessary. A new author has written a good book but is having trouble getting it published. He / She … And the story has a happy ending. Which might include self-publishing and some great marketing. Now - do your research, come up with a great plot, and make it happen. That’s what good authors can do. Yes - that’s what I’d do. Hope this helps.

I’d self-publish it. However, I have done my research on all the various moving parts that go into doing that, and done it successfully for my PR and Marketing clients. If you haven’t bothered to learn what those moving parts are, much less how to manage them, then publishing it yourself isn’t going to work out well for more than 99 in 100 people. The stats are clear—fewer than 1% do more than break even. I’ve seen spectacular results of launching a book properly. But even that can fizzle, as we’re playing the odds with this, not using a guaranteed-to-work checklist. The odds go up, however—significantly higher than 1% for each book. By publishing more than one, and doing each of them effectively, you’ll eventually hit a kind of critical mass that brings the kind of success that snowballs into a writing career. For those who don’t have the time to master a dozen specialties that go into a proper book launch, I strongly recommend you keep writing. Write the next book. Push that to publishers while you write the third one. Eventually, a publisher will want what you’re offering, and you can then tell them you have a back catalog of unpublished MSS. That’s a huge plus to a publisher because it tells them you have more than one book in you, and they can jump on what you already have and may consider a serial launch. Good luck!
